author: Zac
title: Mixel v. Nixel
review:
I’m not a Mixels devotee, and bought this set for its parts and for free shipping. The selection is excellent: among other parts, the four white descending teeth, the four white circular tiles with holes in the middle, and the black “ice cream cone” that holds on the all-seeing eye are all handy to have. For $4.99—and especially for $3.99, what I paid—it’s worth buying for the parts alone.

Having not seen the television show, however, I admit that I do not understand the character. I found playability lacking: the range of motion is limited and no alternate poses are possible. Furthermore, I’m not actually sure what the source material was. Is this surgeon-themed or dentist-themed? An oral surgery theme seems too specific. The combination light/defibrillator suggests an operating room, but Skrubz’ perpetually open mouth simulates that awkward moment at the dentist when one is being talked at but cannot respond. This sums up the character well, I think: immobile and uncharismatic.

This set also includes a Nixel, who looks unhappy or possibly nauseated at the prospect of Skrubz’ gaping maw. Again, the parts are excellent: two black arms, a three-toothed black haircut, and adorably piebald black and white legs. Here the Nixel far exceeds the Mixel in character and posability!
